work.p: This manuscript is a draft of the opening section of Memoranda During the War.

titleStmt.title: [in life]
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: This manuscript was composed prior to the publication of Memoranda During the War in 1875. Parts of "[in life]" appear in slightly altered form in the introduction to Memoranda During the War. Material from the verso, "[that vaster History of the war]," also appears in an altered form as part of the introduction of Memoranda.
The following are responsible for particular readings or for changes to this file, as noted: Elizabeth Lorang Vanessa Steinroetter Ashley Lawson

div1.p: in life, those years, to visit the sick & wounded of the Army, both on the field & in the Hospitals of Washington city & its adjacencies. I found it necessary to keep little note-books—merely sheets of paper, folded, to carry handily in the pocket—for cases, names, incidents, &c. It is tofrom these Memoranda, briefly & rapidly pencilled on the spot that I transcribe quite all the following incidents. Whatever they do not have, they arehave at least the qualities of being written on the spot,amid the scenes, & of presenting what the eyes saw and the heart felt at the time, & probably of conveyingperhaps out of the more or less, the convulsive temper and
These Memoranda, too, are indicated parts of that vaster Unwritten History of the war which has not been & never willcan be, recorded. For inof all that many-threaded drama of conflict

These Such memoranda, The present Note Memoranduma too,too, may furnish for preservation,more definitely a few flitting & lurid glimpses of it, & into those vastervastlurid interiors of the War that period, which have not been & never can be fully carried conveyed to the future. I have attempted only one one phase of it—& that but partially Of all that many th
